key_insight: Integrating autonomous uncertainty quantification into computational point-of-care (POC) sensor pipelines lets neural diagnostic models know when their predictions are unreliable, enabling safer, self-aware on-device decisions.
problem_solved: Neural network diagnostic models for POC sensors can produce confident but incorrect predictions (hallucinations), risking misdiagnosis in remote or resource-limited settings that lack human oversight.
method: Augment neural diagnostic models to output calibrated uncertainty alongside predictions so low-confidence cases are identified.
Implement on-device mechanisms for out-of-distribution detection and decision triggers (e.g., repeat test, escalate to human review) when uncertainty is high.
Use lightweight calibration and UQ techniques suitable for edge deployment to preserve low latency and resource constraints.
impact: Provides a practical path to safer, more trustworthy AI in resource-constrained medical settings by enabling models that autonomously flag unreliable outputs—reducing false reassurance and guiding fallback actions.
visual_elements: End-to-end pipeline diagram showing sensor → neural model → prediction + uncertainty → decision gate (accept / repeat / escalate).
Calibration/reliability diagram comparing predicted confidence vs. actual accuracy before and after UQ calibration.
Sample sensor image or signal with an overlaid uncertainty heatmap to show localized confidence.
Bar chart or table showing reduction in high-confidence errors and number of flagged cases at different uncertainty thresholds.
paper_title: Autonomous Uncertainty Quantification for Computational Point-of-care Sensors
paper_authors: Artem Goncharov, Rajesh Ghosh, Hyou-Arm Joung, Dino Di Carlo, Aydogan Ozcan
